A remaster of the greatest game ever made‚Ä¶ What is not to love? 
This Remaster is (mostly) very dutiful to the original but is updated to run on modern computers with some extra tweaks. Just as a remaster should be.

If you never played the original, then this is an excellent game that I would heartily recommend. However, if you did play the original then the picture becomes more complicated as they both have their merits and both have their downsides. It is worth noting that since the release of the Remaster, you can no longer buy the original. If you can find an old disk set then you can still play of course.

+ The most important positive of the remaster is that the original is so old that many modern computers simply can‚Äôt run the game at a playable framerate. The remaster runs smoothly on a modern system and if you were struggling with this then the remaster is a godsend!
+ Several small unit tweaks have been made to improve the game balance (such as the Armenian infantry morale)
+ Plenty of features have been added and can be toggled on/off. Even if you disagree with changing the population mechanic, you can simply toggle this off. That choice is great (although some choices do get out together which can be frustrating).
+ Most of the original unplayable factions are now accessible.
+ Mod options are significantly expanded.
+ Significant quality of life improvements, including excellent maps on the campaign.
 +/-  Graphics have been updated. I personally prefer the original style and think it has aged quite gracefully.
 
There are plenty of positives so why do I play the original 90% of the time?  
- The original loads much, much quicker
- The UI is much better on the original. This is the one area where they did not dutifully remaster the original. They remade it, and made it worse. It is far clearer and more user friendly in the original and this is the biggest factor by far from me when choosing to play the original.
- There are some weird tweaks seem to have happened like the Phalanx formation - which became significantly more flimsy in the remaster. Seeing a phalanx beaten by a frontal charge of light Greek cavalry is just wrong.
- Similarly, the music doesn‚Äôt pause as the battle is paused. This is a small personal gripe but it does impact the sensation of the battle and some suspense is lost as a result of this change (and this is not something you can toggle on/off).
- The Remastered added some new things like Merchants that feel fairly pointless and whilst you can just toggle this off, it doesn‚Äôt feel true to the original and it becomes grating that they add new features to the game but chose not to improve some of the key issues with the original such as city pathfinding.


It is worth mentioning the DLC. Barbarian Invasion is excellent and provides a similar amount of playtime potential to the main game. This comes with some extra tweaks: Most notably, it included making the emergent factions playable as and when they emerge - this is amazing and probably my favourite thing about the remaster.

The Alexander DLC was always a rushed title with significantly more potential. The remaster missed many opportunities to fix its many problems. This was not remastered at all. You can‚Äôt polish a turd and this game needed some significant changes. They just added polish and resold it. Shame.

At ¬£30. You are getting a great game, 1 excellent DLC and a second DLC that they might as well have ignored seeing as they remastered nothing. This price is OK, but considering a significant amount of buyers probably have/had the original, I don‚Äôt feel it is worth it unless the original game does not run on your modern computer. 

In the end, I will select Recommended here because at its core this is Rome Total War - to me, the best game ever made. But if you have the original and it runs fine on your pc then I personally don‚Äôt think it is worth the money.

The UI can take a bit of getting used to, and I wish that they had kept the original layout of the game, however that is a tradeoff I will make to experience the game in a stable and better looking package. For fans of the era or grand strategy fans in general this is an easy game to recommend, the perfect mix of fun and a rewarding challenge. The battles in this game are quite similar to Medieval II in that if done right you can accomplish incredibly fun victories.

Rome Total War Remastered, a game released in year 2021, feels like a product carried almost entirely by nostalgia rather than genuine quality. Most people who bought it seem to have done so out of affection for the original game, out of frustration with Creative Assembly‚Äôs recent titles, or simply because a few popular YouTubers heavily praised it. But once the initial hype settled, the reality became hard to ignore.

The original Rome: Total War ‚Äî a 20-year-old game ‚Äî still has almost the same number of active players as this Remastered version. And Rome II, a game that many of us initially disliked at launch due to its problems, is today the second most-played Total War title by a large margin. Meanwhile, this Remastered edition struggles to maintain a meaningful player base despite being reviewed as if it were some kind of triumphant return. The numbers tell a very different story.

On a technical level, the game simply isn‚Äôt an upgrade. The interface, HUD, and camera controls feel worse than the original. The realistic textures placed on top of outdated, low-quality models often stretch, glitch, or warp, creating a visual result that feels less immersive and more cartoonish compared to the 2004 game. For something marketed as a visual improvement, the graphics frequently end up looking worse.

Even the modding scene was far stronger in the original. Mods like Rome Surrectum II and Europa Barbarorum were ambitious, polished, and genuinely transformative. The current mod offerings for the Remastered version don‚Äôt come close to what the community achieved on the original engine.

In short, Rome Total War Remastered is treated far more positively than it deserves. If you want the true Rome experience, the original game ‚Äî with its far superior mods and more coherent visual style ‚Äî still offers more depth and charm than this overpriced remaster.

The question rises: who asked for this overpriced cash grab? It‚Äôs a barely functional coat of paint over a 20-year-old game. While the original's core strategic brilliance is still faintly visible, the remaster manages to smother it with poor design choices. The new UI is an atrocious, clunky mess that is somehow less intuitive than the original's 2004 interface, making the management of provinces a chore rather than a pleasure. Of course, the infamous unit pathfinding issues are still present, leading to units freezing mid-battle or running in confused circles, completely ruining the immersion, and even on the campaign map sometimes the AI gets stuck. Add persistent, frustrating crashes, especially in the late game, and what you're left with is a disappointingly buggy and cumbersome experience. If you still own the original, stick to it.

Until then: Veni, Vidi, Uninstalli !
